metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (automatic weather station of Heihe remote sensing station, 2016)
metadata.description:
This data set contains meteorological element observation data of heihe remote sensing station in the middle reaches of heihe hydrometeorological observation network from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016.The station is located in the east of dangzhai town, zhangye city, gansu province.The longitude and latitude of the observation point are 100.4756e, 38.8270n and 1560m above sea level.The air temperature and humidity sensor is located at 1.5m, facing due north.The barometer is in the waterproof box;The tilting bucket rain gauge is installed at 0.7 m;The wind speed and direction sensor is located at 10m, facing due north;The installation height of the four-component radiometer is 1.5m, facing due south;The installation height of the two infrared thermometers is 1.5m, facing due south and the probe facing vertically downward.The soil temperature probe is buried at 0cm on the surface and 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm underground.The soil water probe was buried at 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm.Average soil temperature probes were buried in 2cm and 4cm;The soil heat flow plate (3 pieces) is buried 6cm underground.Two photosynthetically active radiometers were set up 1.5m above the canopy (one probe vertically upwards and one probe vertically downwards), facing due south.
Observation projects are: air temperature and humidity (Ta_1. 5 m, RH_1. 5 m) (unit: c, percentage), pressure (Press) (unit: hundred mpa), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), wind speed (WS_10m) (unit: m/s), wind (WD_10m) (unit: degrees), the radiation of four component (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watts per square meter), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit:C), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (in watts/m2), soil temperature (Ts_0cm, Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_120cm, Ts_160cm) (in:C), soil moisture (Ms_0cm, Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_80cm, Ms_120cm, Ms_160cm) (unit: %), upward and downward photosynthetically active radiation (PAR_U_up, PAR_U_down) (unit: micromole/sq.s), mean soil temperature (TCAV) (unit: Celsius).
Processing and quality control of observed data :(1) ensure 144 pieces of data every day (every 10min), and mark by -6999 in case of data missing;2016.1.01-1.29 due to collector problems, many observation elements have more error values;(2) excluding the time with duplicate records;(3) data that obviously exceeds the physical significance or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked with red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) date and time have the same format, and date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2016-6-10-10:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
For information of hydrometeorological network or station, please refer to Liu et al. (2018), and for observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al. (2011).

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Verification.Question: Are multiscale observations necessary to accurately capture eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the main challenge in collecting data for evapotranspiration estimation more related to image classification errors, atmospheric conditions, or instrumentation limitations?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the common challenges faced during data collection in arid and semi-arid regions for hydrometeorological studies?
Where can datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas be accessed?
When are the thermal radiation measurements typically conducted during the field observations in the Daman superstation?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that integrates both ground-based and airborne remote sensing techniques for eco-hydrological studies in oasis-desert systems?
Example.Answer: Several intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, including a superstation within the oasis, EC towers, automatic meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing missions using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting multiscale observations for studying eco-hydrological processes in arid regions?
Example.Answer: One challenge in collecting multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes is the poor availability of such data, which hinders progress in understanding and upscaling these processes on heterogeneous surfaces, as indicated by the HiWATER experiment's design to address this issue.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert areas?
Example.Answer: The dataset from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes from 2012 to 2021, captured through eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations, and is available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key features of the hydrometeorological observation network used in data collection for eco-hydrological studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: automatic weather stations, eddy covariance towers, flux observation matrix, air temperature, wind speed, humidity, radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles

Feature Specification.Question: What features define the multi-scale dataset used to study the oasis-desert interaction in arid regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: hierarchical, multidisciplinary, flux measurements via eddy covariance systems, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, eco-hydrological data, soil moisture, leaf area index, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data, LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, microwave radiometers, synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics, photosynthesis processes

Quantification.Question: What is the frequency of meteorological parameter measurements in a typical data collection method within the field?
During a specific observation experiment, how many days of data were used to determine evapotranspiration and related ratios?

Definition.Question: What is a multiscale dataset in the context of eco-hydrological studies?
Definition.Answer: A multiscale dataset in eco-hydrological studies refers to a collection of data obtained from diverse observational tools and techniques across different spatial scales, designed to capture complex processes in heterogeneous landscapes. This includes data from instruments such as eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and airborne remote sensing technologies.

Definition.Question: What does quality control entail in the process of data collection for hydrometeorological observations?
Definition.Answer: Quality control in hydrometeorological data collection involves ensuring data accuracy and reliability through sensor calibration, careful data collection, processing, and generation of datasets. It includes the identification and removal of erroneous data, standardization of measurement protocols, and maintaining consistency in data formats.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of remote sensing technologies with ground-based measurements improve the accuracy and comprehensiveness of data collection in eco-hydrological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers with ground-based measurements like eddy covariance systems and automatic meteorological stations provides a multiscale and multidisciplinary dataset. This combination allows for capturing detailed eco-hydrological processes across different scales, improving the understanding of interactions between oasis and desert systems and enhancing the accuracy of water vapor, energy, and carbon exchange measurements.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the combination of stable isotope techniques and eddy covariance measurements enhance the validation of evapotranspiration estimates in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: The combination of stable isotope techniques with eddy covariance measurements allows for the separate validation of evaporation and transpiration components of evapotranspiration. This method provides better validation of observed ratios of evaporation and transpiration to total evapotranspiration, particularly in strongly advective environments. It helps in addressing uncertainties in temperature differences and component temperature estimations, thus enhancing the accuracy of the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model's performance.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to available energy and the uncertainty in surface–air temperature differences. The errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures also significantly affect the performance of models like the TSEB model.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the high uncertainty in estimating latent heat fluxes using models like the TSEB model in irrigated farmland?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high uncertainty in estimating latent heat fluxes using the TSEB model in irrigated farmland arises from errors in the derived component temperatures caused by image classification errors, atmospheric conditions not being fully accounted for, and the uncertainty in the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy. These factors lead to incorrect estimations of soil and canopy component temperatures and subsequently affect the model's performance.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of hierarchical scale instrumentation in data collection influence the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of hierarchical scale instrumentation, such as in the HiWATER experiment, enhances the understanding of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and oasis-desert interactions by providing comprehensive and multiscale observational data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the effects of incorporating long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange on the understanding of oasis-desert ecosystem dynamics?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange provides crucial insights into the energy balance, carbon peaking, and the sustainable development of oasis-desert ecosystems, supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary intention behind collecting multiscale and multidisciplinary data in the context of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary intention is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, a task hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. Multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection aims to capture these processes more accurately and provide comprehensive insights into oasis-desert interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to implement a robust data collection strategy for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is essential to implement a robust data collection strategy to quantitatively understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This understanding is crucial for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development within these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to ensure quality control and data processing in hydrometeorological observations in oasis-desert areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality control in hydrometeorological observations involves data collection, data processing, and data archiving. Observational data are carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. The data processing and quality control procedure specifically includes monitoring sensor calibration and ensuring the integrity of data collected from automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, and scintillometers.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multiscale eco-hydrological processes captured using instrumentation in hierarchical networks in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multiscale eco-hydrological processes are captured through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, which involves arranging instruments in sparse networks to investigate oasis-desert interactions. This includes setting up superstations, eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and executing airborne remote sensing missions using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers to capture data across different scales and landscapes.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in collecting accurate multiscale hydrometeorological data in oasis-desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in collecting accurate multiscale hydrometeorological data in oasis-desert systems may stem from the poor availability of multiscale observations and the complexity of capturing eco-hydrological processes across different scales, as noted in the HiWATER experiment.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the uncertainties in surface flux estimation using remote sensing and ground-based data in arid agricultural areas?
Expectation.Answer: Uncertainties in surface flux estimation could be influenced by errors in determining soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures and the strong advective environment in irrigated agricultural areas, which affect models like the TSEB.

Expectation.Question: Why is it critical to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in terms of data collection and analysis for sustainable development?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining a balance is critical to understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are essential for achieving carbon neutrality and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development in oasis-desert areas, especially under climate change pressures.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways might multiscale datasets improve the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems, and what are the potential challenges in collecting such data?
Judgmental.Answer: Multiscale datasets provide comprehensive insights into eco-hydrological processes by capturing data at various scales, which can help address the challenge of upscaling processes on heterogeneous surfaces. However, challenges include the poor availability of multiscale observations and the complexity of capturing interactions within the oasis-desert system.

Judgmental.Question: What is the significance of long-term observational datasets in assessing the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems, and what factors contribute to the reliability of such data collections?
Judgmental.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, supporting ecological sustainability, and informing socio-economic development. The reliability of these datasets depends on systematic data processing, quality control, and the integration of comprehensive hydrometeorological and ecological measurements.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how multiscale observations are effectively managed to study eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems.
Assertion.Answer: Multiscale observations are managed through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. This involves a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, including LiDAR and imaging spectrometers.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how data quality is maintained across different hydrometeorological observations in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality is maintained through careful quality control, which includes sensor calibration, data processing, and the generation of datasets. Observational data are collected with a high degree of precision and consistency, ensuring reliable multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data for eco-hydrological processes in oasis–desert systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data in oasis–desert systems involve using a hierarchically nested observation system. This includes a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; along with synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. Multiple intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations are conducted to capture eco-hydrological processes at multiple scales.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in obtaining accurate surface flux measurements in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in obtaining accurate surface flux measurements in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas include the incomplete energy balance closure of EC flux measurements with respect to available energy. Errors also arise from image classification errors when deriving component temperatures, which vary with vegetation abundance. This leads to uncertainty in the TSEB model and the EC system, particularly when the mean sensible heat flux (H) is small. Additionally, uncertainties in atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, as well as estimation of incoming short- and long-wave radiation, contribute to errors in Rn estimation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could be used to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, and discuss their availability.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas include long-term observations of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are collected using eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations, with data on radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature, humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Additionally, groundwater table data, vegetation, and soil parameters are included. Such datasets are available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
